lines.text: A lot of weather we've been having lately!
That's the first mistake we've made since that fellow sold us the Brooklyn Bridge.
Buying that bridge was no mistake. That's going to be worth a lot of money to us some day.
Well, fan my brow! I'm from the South!
You are?
Well, shut my mouth! I'm from the South too!
The South of what, sir?
The South of London.
Tell me, tell me about my dear, dear Daddy! Is it true that he's dead?
Well, we hope he is, they buried him.
Your hat's dry.
Oh that reminds me, you made a statement this afternoon.
Did I?
Mmm-hmmm. You said if we didn't get the deed, you'd eat my hat.
Oh, now you're taking me literally.
Nevertheless, I'm going to teach you not to make rash promises.
[Puts hat in his lap]
Eat the hat.
Oh that's silly. Whoever heard of anybody eating a hat?
Whoever heard of anybody doing *that*.
[Immitates Stan's thumb lighter gimmick]
Eat the hat!

[Gives it back]
I won't do it.

[Slams it back in his lap]
If you don't eat that hat, I'll tie you to a tree and let the buzzards get you!
Would you really do that?
I certainly would.
[Stan says something incoherant due to him crying]

[Showing no sympathy]
Eat it.

[merely and naively referring to someone who mines for gold, unaware that -A- neither Lola nor Mary would be expected to dirty their pretty little hands by actually hefting a shovel themselves, or that -B- the term "gold digger" also means a woman who tries to get money out of unsuspecting men, and that Lola already IS a "gold digger"]
Now that you own a gold mine, I bet you'll be a swell gold-digger.
''every cloud has a silver lining''.

[in an attempt to wax poetic like Ollie]
That's right - any bird can build a nest, but it isn't every one that can lay an egg.
We'll all go down to Dixie. Oh, for a slice of possum and yam. Mm!
Yes sir, and some good old fish and chips. I can smell 'em.

[disgusted]
Fish and chips!
This is another nice mess you've gotten me into!

[having just gotten a tearful earful from his distraught wife about The Boys' having romantically harassed her on the coach]
Fiddlin', huh?
[absent-mindedly nods in agreement, then hastily shakes his head rapidly and forcefully, realizing that he should not be admitting to any wrongdoing]

Well... we don't like your kind around these parts! And there's one thing in this here town - - we DON'T allow! And that's messing with our women! Now, if you want to stay healthy, you'll catch the next coach out of town.
Yes, sir. We'll be right on our way just as soon as we finish up with our business.
And if you MISS the next coach...
[draws revolver]
You'll be riding out of here in a HEARSE!

[slides the gun back into his holster with an angry shove]
G'day, strangers!
[walks away huffily]

[with an innocently cheerful friendly wave after the departing sheriff, showing that he fails to grasp the gravity of the situation]
Goodbye...!

[hastiy shushing him]
Let well enough alone!
Hey Finn, you're a lucky man to have a swell gal like that.
Yeah I... What are you talking about? She's the lucky one to have a swell guy like me!
It can't be. What did he die of?
I think he died of a Tuesday, or was it a Wednesday?
Do you mind if I have another idea?
If it's anything like the last one, yes.

[Every time Mickey pushes $1 on the bar's cash register, the amount of $.10 comes up in the display; to bartender]
Hey. This thing ain't working right.
It's working all right for me.
We want to know why you're not Mary Roberts!
Wait a minute, while I spit on me hands.
Little Lady, you've heard the worst.
[smiles]
Now prepare yourself for the best.

[shows Finn the deed]
Ha - *ha*!
Ho - *ho*!

[grabs the deed]
He - *he*!
I'm Mary's legal guardian. What do you want to see her for?

[smiling and shutting his eyes in his famous charming disarming way]
Well, sir, we aren't supposed to talk about that to anyone else.

[attempting to speak in a serious, slightly self-important tone, but obviously just blabbing away carelessly]
Yeah, you see, it's PRIVATE. Her father died and left her a gold mine, and we're not supposed tell it to anyone but her, right Ollie?

[looking disgusted at Stan's stupidity]
Now that he's taken you into our CONFIDENCE...
[gives Stan an annoyed shove]
You might as well know the rest!
Can you do it?

[scoffs]
Can I do it? For a gold mine, I could be Cleopatra!

[hearing a knock on the door]
Who's there?
Mary.
Mary who?

[panicking]
Mary... Mary Christmas!

[sung]
Some ball / Commence to dancin' / Commence to prancin' / Commence advancin' / Right and left a-glancin' / A moochee dancin' / Slide and glide entrancin' / You do the tango jiggle with a Texas Tommy wiggle / You take your partner and you hold her / Slightly enfold her / A little bolder / Just work your shoulder, snap your fingers one and all / In the hall at the ball, that's ah- ah - all

[enters room]
Lola, Lola, we've got a fortune right in the palm of our hand!
What do you mean?
There's a couple of desert rats downstairs looking for Mary Roberts.
What about it?
They've got a deed to a very valuable gold mine left to her by her father, and they're here to deliver it to her in person.
Well, ain't that just grand!
It would be... if you were Mary Roberts.
I gotcha, but I'd never get away with it.
Sure you would; they've never seen Mary Roberts.
Then it's a cinch!

[from the staircase]
Hey! If you come upstairs, I'll introduce you to Mary Roberts.
Right away, sir.

[enters from the kitchen]
Did you call me, Mr. Finn?

[runs down the stairs]
Ohhh! Get back into the kitchen where you belong! Go ahead now, don't bother me!
[goes up the stairs to his residence]
This way gentlemen, come right this way.
[stumbles on the staircase]

[the real Mary knocks at the door]
Who's there?
Mary.
Mary who?

[nervously]
Mary - Merry Christmas. Ohhh...
[opens the door]
Excuse me, Mr. Finn, one of these gentlemen dropped this at the foot of the stairs.

[takes the deed from her hands, not recognizing her as the real Mary]
Oh, oh why thank you, little lady, you don't know what you've done, thanks!

[shows Mary out of the room, closing the door]
All right, all right, all right.
signed, sealed, and now delivered.
Oh, thank you so much.
Not at all.
[Mickey Finn utters a sigh of exhausted relief]
Come Stanley, we'd better be going.
Oh say, what about the locket?
That's right I...
We've got something else for you.
I almost forgot it.
[puts on his derby and loosens his necktie]
And besides that...
[unbuttons his shirt and takes out the locket]
your father left you this family heirloom.
Oh yes, I - I remember it well.
Help me get it off, Stanley.
[Ollie loosens his collar while Stan tries to take the locket chain off of Ollie's neck by pulling it up around his chin]
Am I hurting you?
No, just a minute.
Won't be long.
[Stan tries again to take the chain off of Ollie]
Maybe I'd better try and open it again.
I think so.
[Stan loosens Ollie's collar to get to the clasp]
It slipped.
[Stan unbuttons Ollie's shirt]
Maybe you'd better take your coat off.

[starts to take off his coat]
Pardon me just a minute.
[Stan removes Ollie's necktie and collar; Ollie takes his suspenders off and the locket falls down his trousers leg to the floor]

[Stan reaches up Ollie's back and finds a thread, Ollie breaks the thread and discovers an unraveled undergarment]
We'll find it in just a moment.
[Ollie takes off his shirt, and Stan notices the locket on the floor and picks it up]
We got it.
[Stan hands the locket to Lola]
I'm gonna go in and change, pardon us.
[Ollie goes into the bedroom to put his clothes back on, and Stan follows]

[Ollie lays his clothes on the bed, Stan sits down]
Say Ollie?
What?
Now that you've got your clothes off, why don't you take a bath?,
Would you mind leaving the room? Can't I ever have a little privacy?
I was just trying to kill two birds with one stone.

[in the living room]
And I'll take care of those two bozos and get them out of town.

[Stan opens the door and overhears Lola talking to Mickey]
Don't worry, leave everything to me. I've done pretty good up to now, haven't I?
You certainly have, I wish you were in my shoes.
Eh-hrm, oh how about a drink on the house?
That suits me fine.
How'd you get dressed so quick?
None of your business.
[Finn goes to open his front door]
Goodbye Miss Roberts, and thanks for the use of your boudoir.
You're very welcome.
Goodbye. Now that you've got the mine, I bet you'll be a swell gold-digger.
[Ollie pushes Stan out the door as Finn leaves the room]

[Lola examines the deed as Finn re-enters the room a moment later, hiding the deed behind her back]
What did you leave them for?
I'll send her right up, you have her sign that deed over to us.
Oh, don't worry about me, get those guys out of town, and pronto!
All right!
[Finn goes down to the saloon]
What a cinch!
On a mountain in Virginia / Stands a lonesome pine / Just below is the cabin home / Of a little girl of mine
lines.character: Lead Singer of the Avalon Boys

lines.text: Her name is June and very, very soon / She'll belong to me / For I know she's waiting there for me / 'Neath that lone pine tree

In the Blue Ridge mountains of Virginia / On the trail of the lonesome pine / In the pale moonshine, our hearts entwine / Where she carved her name and I carved mine / Oh June, just like the mountains, I'm blue / Like the pine, I am lonesome for you
Oo, oo, oo
In the Blue Ridge mountains of Virginia / On the trail of the lonesome pine

[Stan starts singing in a deep bass voice]
In the Blue Ridge mountains of Virginia / On the trail of the lonesome pine / In the pale moonshine, our hearts entwine / Where she carved her name and I carved mine /
[Ollie talks to the bartender, who gives him a mallet]
/ Oh June, like the mountains I'm blue / Like the pine, I am lonesome for you

[Ollie hits Stan with a mallet; Stan's voice changes to a high falsetto]
In the Blue Ridge mountains of Virginia / On the trail of the lonesome piiiine
[song ends with Stan falling down; his head hits a cuspidor and he snores]

[Mary comes downstairs]
Goodbye, Miss... uh... Miss... uh...
Roberts, Mary Roberts.
Goodbye, Miss Roberts.
Goodbye.

[Stan and Ollie stop walking, Ollie does a double take]
Did you hear what she said her name was?
Sure, Mary Roberts.
How can she be Mary Roberts when we've just given the deed to Mary Roberts?
I don't know.
[Stan crushes out a cigar butt with his shoe]
I smell a rat.
I smell something too.
[Stan discovers his shoe is smoking from the cigar butt, dunks his feet into the janitor's water pail]
Come on.
[Stan and Ollie go back to the kitchen; they remove their hats]
Pardon me, did you ever have a father by the name of Cy Roberts?
Why, yes. He left me here with these people years ago when he went prospecting.
Well, who's that woman upstairs?
That's Lola Marcel, Mr. Finn's wife. She's my legal guardian now.

[Stan taps Ollie on the shoulder, and accidentally bangs his head on a hanging frying pan]
Can I speak to you for a minute?
Pardon us.
Yeah, we'll be right back.
[Stan and Ollie head for the main hall]
You know what?
What?
I think we've given that deed to the wrong woman. That's the first mistake we've made since that guy sold us the Brooklyn Bridge.
Oh, buying that bridge was no mistake. That's gonna be worth a lot of money to us someday.
Well, maybe you're right. We'd better go and get the deed.
Say, maybe they won't give it back to us.
What do you mean, they won't give it back to us? We'll get that deed, or I'll eat your hat.
That's what I call determination.
[Ollie shakes Stan's hand; they head upstairs]
Come on.

[Ollie knocks on the door]
Who's there?
Me.
Me who?

[annoyed]
"Me who?"
[Ollie knocks again, this time on Mickey Finn's head]

[Ollie knocks on Mickey Finn's door]
Who's there?
Me.
Me, who?

[annoyed at Stan's response]
"Me, who?"
[Mickey Finn goes to the door, Ollie knocks on his head]
Well - What do you want?
Out of my way, you snake in the grass!
[Ollie brushes Finn aside]
You toad in the hole.
[Stan yanks Finn's necktie, Finn kicks Stan in retaliation]
Say you slugs, what do you mean busting in here like this?
We want to know why you are not Mary Roberts.
I'll take care of this matter.
So you got wise, huh? Well, if it's this deed you're after, you're just out of luck.
[Ollie grabs the deed from Lola, and a chase ensues]
Give that back to me!
Take it, Stan!
[Ollie pursues Mickey Finn]
Beat it!

[holding a pistol]
Now, get out of here!
[knock on the door]
Who's there?
The sheriff.
Just in the nick of time! Now we'll get justice! Come in, Sheriff, you're just the man I'm looking for!
And you're just the man I'm looking for.
Oh thank you, this man -
[Ollie recognizes the Sheriff whose wife was pestered by Stan and Ollie in the stagecoach]
Ohhh!
[Stan laughs hysterically]

[Ollie taps Stan on the shoulder, he stops laughing]
I thought I told you two dudes to catch the next coach out of town.

[meekly]
Yes, sir.
Well, it left ten minutes ago.
It did? Well, maybe we'd better try and catch it.
Well, I'd say you'd better!
[the Sheriff fires his guns, chasing Stan and Ollie out of town]
Look at 'em go!
Ha, you can't see 'em for dust!
[Sheriff laughs]
Have you seen my husband?
Yeah, there he is, over there.

[sings]
Won't you be my ownsome / My little turtle dove?

[starts hugging the miner]
Will I?
[laughs, Lola goes back to the stage]
Waiter, I want a big bottle of wine, right over here! Come on, bring it over here, this beer's no good!
[the miner's wife confronts him]

[continues singing]
My loving honey man...

[closes his eyes, thinking he's kissing Lola]
Sweetheart!
[opens his eyes to discover he just kissed his wife, who escorts him out of the saloon]
Oh!
[last lines]

[singing]
We're going to go, we're going to go / We're going to go way down in Dixie / Where the hens are doggone glad to lay / Scrambled eggs in the new-mown hay / We're going to see, we're going to see / We're going to see my home in Dixie / You can tell the world we're going to...

[music stops]
I know how to spell it.

[music resumes]
Then we're going,

[sings separately]
All right, we're going,
You know we're going,

[sings]
You bet we're going
To our home in Dixie land / We're going to go way down in Dixie / Where the hens are doggone glad to lay / Scrambled eggs in the new-mown hay / We're going to see, we're going to see...
[song fades out as Ollie falls into the creek]
On a mountain in Virginia / Stands a lonesome pine / Just below is the cabin home / Of a little girl of mine

Oo-oo-oo
In the Blue Ridge mountains of Virginia / On the trail of the lonesome pine

[Stan starts singing in a deep bass voice]
In the Blue Ridge mountains of Virginia / On the trail of the lonesome pine / In the pale moonshine, our hearts entwine / Where she carved her name and I carved mine /
[Ollie talks to the bartender, who gives him a mallet]
/ Oh June, like the mountains I'm blue / Like the pine, I am lonesome for you

[Ollie hits Stan with a mallet; Stan's voice changes to a high falsetto]
In the Blue Ridge mountains of Virginia / On the trail of the lonesome piiiine
[song ends with Stan falling down; his head hits a cuspidor and he snores]

[crowd chants "We want Lola! We want Lola! We want Lola!"]
And now gentlemen, it has always been my aim to give you the best entertainment that money can buy. I have brought here at great expense...
Aw, get a piece of fat and slide off!
Who said that?
[a customer fires a gun and the shot blows Finn's top hat from his head, laughter and a scream are heard]
All right, you'll get Lola!

[singing]
Commence advancin', commence advancin'/ Just start a prancin', right and left a-glancin'/ A moochee dancin', slide and glide entrancin'/ You do the tango jiggle/ With a Texas Tommy wiggle...
Now that you've got your clothes off, why don't you take a bath.
Would you mind leaving the room. Can't I ever have a little privacy?
Well, I was just trying to kill two birds with one stone.
Goodbye, Miss Roberts and thanks for the use of your - boudoir.

[singing]
In the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia/ On the trail of the lonesome pine...
Goodbye, Miss, eh, Miss, eh...
Roberts. Mary Roberts.
Goodbye Miss Roberts.
Goodbye.
[Mary leaves. Stan and Ollie start to walk out and suddenly stop]
Did you hear what she said her name was?
Sure. Mary Roberts.
How can she be Mary Roberts when we've just given the deed to Mary Roberts?
I smell a rat!
I smell something too.
Splendid. Splendid!
She fell for it, like you fell for me.
Lola, my gal, we're sittin' pretty.
What do you want?
Out of my way, you snake in the grass!
You toad in the hole.
Say, you slugs, what do you mean busting in here like this?
We want to know why you are not Mary Roberts!
I thought I told you two dudes to catch the next coach out of town.
Yes sir.
Well, it left ten minutes ago.
It did? Well, maybe we'd better try and catch it.
[Stan and Ollie race out]
Shhhhh!
Shhhhh!
Shhhhh!

[singing]
We're going to go/ We're going to go/ We're going to go way down in Dixie/ Where the hens are doggone glad to lay/ Scrambled eggs in the new mown hay...
[Finn pushes the $1 key on the cash register and .10 shows up, he opens the cash register case to examine it, and .10 appears when he presses the $1 key again]
[first lines]
Hey, this thing ain't workin' right.
It's working all right for me.
[Finn does a double take]
